<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module7_mcq_q51')" data-correct-answer="C">
<strong style="display: block;">Firms A and B are identical except for their capital structures. Both operate with $r_U = 10\%$ and $r_D = 5\%$ (no taxes). Firm A has $D/E = 0.5$, while Firm B has $D/E = 1.5$. According to Modigliani and Miller Proposition II, by how many percentage points is Firm B’s cost of equity higher than Firm A’s?</strong>

<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q51" value="A"> A. 2.0 p.p.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q51" value="B"> B. 3.5 p.p.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q51" value="C"> C. 5.0 p.p.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q51" value="D"> D. 6.0 p.p.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q51" value="E"> E. 7.5 p.p.</label><br>
</form>

<div id="feedback-module7_mcq_q51" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: C.  
Under MM Proposition II (no taxes), $r_E = r_U + \frac{D}{E}(r_U - r_D)$.  

For Firm A:  
$r_E^A = 0.10 + 0.5(0.10 - 0.05) = 0.125 = 12.5\%$.  

For Firm B:  
$r_E^B = 0.10 + 1.5(0.10 - 0.05) = 0.175 = 17.5\%$.  

Thus, the cost of equity increases by $17.5\% - 12.5\% = 5.0$ percentage points when leverage rises from 0.5 to 1.5 — illustrating the linear relationship between risk and leverage.
</div>
